question: You bowed to Lady Gaga?
What did he say to you?
What do you call the president?
answer: Oh, when I see him I call him Barack or President Obama or Mr. President.

question: How do you do?
How old are you?
answer: I am turning 21 in two weeks.

question: How did you do this?
answer: I have a fantastic publicity team.

question: I mean, you weren't even -- you weren't doing anything before you got this job, were you?
answer: No, no, I was just a student and I was in high school a few months before I got the show, and then I was in college for two weeks, and then when I officially got it and -- I was working at a dry cleaner's in the summers to --

question: Earning how much?
answer: I think it was -- oh, gosh!

question: -- about "Glee"?
answer: Well, I was driving back from the last audition, and I was -- my mom, my mom was driving.

question: What's the look?
answer: The look was -- like, it looked like she should be driving, she should be paying attention to the road.

question: Did you have an inkling?
I mean, who could've predicted all of this?
Were you thinking in your head, "I really want to be" -- I don't know, whoever?
Tom Cruise, you know?
Zac Efron?
Who are your idols?
answer: No, I never thought I would ever be of heartthrob stature.

question: Who were your celebrity icons?
Well, not actually Oprah?
Really?
Did you want to be an actor?
answer: Yes, ever since -- I remember I was, like, 3 years old, and I was watching a movie, the title of which escapes me, but -- and I remember the credits came on.

question: When did it pop for you?
Oh, God -- what was the first "pinch me" moment?
answer: The moment when you rang your mum and you were both getting carried away on the phone.

question: Yes?
answer: When I signed up for "America's Got Talent."

question: Yes?
answer: I mean, the first day of filming the live shows was through those famous gates.

question: Now, that is a moment, isn't it?
answer: Yes, it's an amazing feeling, it is.

question: It's just kids who feel they're outsiders, right?
But as you were walking up, you just thought -- what were you thinking?
answer: I remember when I was walking up, I kept thinking to myself: do not trip on a chair or a table on the way up there, because it was so possible, because there were so many things in my way.

question: Do you remember their names?
Is there anyone in particular that you'd like to just smoke out now?
answer: No, I hated them all equally, no.

question: How did it make you feel?
answer: I was just embarrassed, because -- I mean, I would walk by these people that I barely knew in the hallway, and they'd just scream profanities at me that I didn't think were true at the time.

question: To me, she's just a phenomenon who completely gets what it takes to be a modern-day brand, doesn't she?
Did you meet her when she came on?
What did you make of her?
answer: Well, I completely embarrassed myself to no end.

question: You bowed to Lady Gaga?
What did she say to you?
Did you have to, then, do anything else?
Did you get to have a proper conversation with her?
answer: No, I don't think I'll ever be able to have a proper conversation with her after that.

question: You'd be too nervous?
answer: I'd be way too -- yes, right.

question: Is she like an iconic figure for you?
answer: I -- you know, she's actually one of the first people in my generation whose music I liked.

question: I bet they're just all over you like a rash about "Glee," right?
Do you ever say to them, "I know how you voted"?
But do you think that they will ever change their mind because you give them a picture?
You know who they are when they ask you?
And you know how they voted?
I mean, do you feel like you're winning when you have that moment with them?
Or do you feel that as gay rights become much more prominent and successes are being achieved, in a funny way, it's becoming in certain pockets, more homophobic as they try and resist this change?
answer: I don't know, because I know that I surround myself with positivity towards the situation and not negativity.

question: What kind of things?
answer: It was just -- high school again.

question: And that hurt?
answer: Yes, because I mean, it's ridiculous when people have like strong opinions about you when it's about things you can't control.

question: It's all hand-in-hand, isn't it?
What did your mother say when she saw this?
It's what mothers do, isn't it?
I mean, are you finding that you're getting more attractive because of the fame?
It's like fame is such a sort of magnet to people, isn't it?
That goes with the territory, doesn't it?
Do you think you're -- are you equipped to deal with all this?
And what's behind-the-scenes stuff with you?
answer: You know, like the security risks and the security issues that are very frightening that people don't know about, because I don't want them to know about.

question: What's the scariest thing that's happened to you?
answer: I was at a movie theater once, and I was by myself, stupidly, and I was semi-mobbed.

question: As it was going on, what were you thinking?
It was crazy, right?
answer: It's crazy, but I mean, in -- it's really a mind trip because, on one hand, you're -- you want them to stop.

question: Have you had stalkers?
Some form of stalking is flattering, you know?
I mean, how can you trust people?
Life's a gamble, though, isn't it?
How do you get your tears to work?
answer: It's really just a -- kind of like a glancing.

question: Can you do it now?
How long would it take you to get into tear mode?
answer: Well, it depends on the scene.

question: A minute?
You could get tears in a couple of seconds?
Why not?
Is it like a magician revealing his secrets?
You're feeling awkward about it?
To order?
answer: No -- no, I mean it's -- no, because sometimes you just can't do it because your body can't produce tears, so you can't.

question: Really?
When was the last time?
So, you're not actually that emotional off camera?
All that bullying, all that ostracizing?
-- steelier side to you than you had when you were growing up?
answer: I think it made me a very sarcastic person, for sure.

question: When did you finish working on this scene?
answer: We finished season two yesterday at 4:00 in the morning.

question: And do you now get time off, or what happens?
And you're also doing a movie in all this?
How are you going to fit that in?
answer: Well, the tour ends on July 5th or 4th, I believe, and as soon as it's over, I am literally going straight to a plane and flying to the set in LA.

question: Do you get any time off at all?
Even a day?
answer: Maybe -- I'll get like a day here and there.

question: That's it, right?
Is there anything else you're up to, other than all this?
Or is that enough this year, is it?
Of all the famous people you've met, who's been the most inspiring to you when you actually met them?
Did you meet the president?
What did he say to you?
Did he know you?
He didn't say he watched it religiously?
answer: No, no, he wasn't like, "Oh, I loved you in 'Single Ladies.'"

question: Yes, what was she like with you?
So, your mother isn't getting demanding about fame, now, right?
answer: A little bit, a little bit, a little bit, yes.

question: I mean, that's a bummer, isn't it?
answer: For some people it could be.

question: I mean, are you proud to be Michelle Obama's older brother?
Are you amazed at how she's dealt with becoming first lady?
Who grows up on the south side of Chicago and, as you pointed out, very modest background, and ends up being the first lady?
What do you call the president now, when you see him?
answer: Oh, when I see him I call him Barack or President Obama or Mr. President.

question: Doesn't it feel even stranger calling him Mr. President?
Had you heard of him before?
answer: You know, I had heard she was dating a guy who was a Harvard guy and they worked together in the summer and this, that, and the other.

question: Is it as simple as those things that he was doing means he's a good man?
answer: You know, it's hard when you get fatigued to shield your real personality.

question: When was the moment -- when Michelle was dating Barack, when was the moment that you realized this guy may be something special politically?
answer: Oh, I had no idea at the time when I met him.

question: What's the moment like for you personally, on a human level, when you walk into the White House for the first time with your brother-in-law as the president of the United States?
answer: Well, I got to tell you, the first thing, Piers, that struck me was how small the inside of the White House was.

question: It's a lot smaller than you think, isn't it?
But was it a surreal moment for you?
Something that annoys you most when you see them described as whatever?
answer: You know, I would love to tell you that there was something that bothers me, but nothing that anybody says bothers me.

question: You never did?
How did you feel when you discovered that your brother- in-law had ordered the mission, the successful mission that killed Osama bin Laden?
answer: Well, I have to say I was probably like most of the people who heard the news.

question: And, finally, will you be out on the stump for him next election campaign?
You're threatening me with physical violence, aren't you?
